Title: Metonymy
References: ŠTULAJTEROVÁ, A., JESENSKÁ, P.: English Stylistics. 1. vyd. Banská Bystrica : Univerzita Mateja Bela, 2013. 114 s.
Content:
A metonymy is a figure of speech that replaces the name of a thing with the name os something else with which it is closely associated. 

Such a close relation may be may ussually be contained in the relation between the cause and the effect or the thing and the person.

examples:

  • to read Shakespeare - you are not reading a person
  • England decites to raise taxes. - England meaning the government

The most significant kind of metonymy is a synecdoche. It refers to a thing by using a name for one of its parts,

  • I have got some new wheels. - wheels meaning the whole car

or can use the name for the whole to represent a part.

  • Chicago won the game. - not the whole city, just the sports team.
